Nah, Bedrock Wither is great. I just beat it for the first time yesterday. Finished half of its health on Hard difficulty and would have continued if it wasn’t for a massive amount of lag, not having a Smite sword, getting myself trapped in Bedrock all the time and having my milk and potions blown up since I didn’t close the walls of my obsidian room. I switched it to Easy on the second half, and it was almost nothing; it wouldn’t have been fair to deal with withering with the massive amount of lag I hadI would have kept it on Normal at least if it wasn’t for all of the tragedies I mentioned. I didn’t even trap it under bedrock. My point is, it’s incredibly hard, but it’s not impossible, I only tuned the difficulty down cause the fight unexpectedly messed up. I think the way it is on Bedrock should be how hard it is; the game is already really easy and the Bedrock Wither is one of the only things that make up for that, that’s provided you don’t cheese it like most people do. It heavily depends on difficulty and strategy. I just made it hard and even unfair for myself by starting on Hard and spawning it right above Bedrock, but I still managed to survive and kill it legitimately.

I agree the wither is to op at least downgrade it's power ups like the rush the wither is already hard to beat when its shooting its skulls and calling upon its wither guards.  It's OP to a point were its even hard to kill in creative.  Its moves too fast and it's way too OP to be a mob in just general.  Lower the health or do something to make it less OP.

The wither in bedrock edition is legitimately ridiculous. Double health compared to java, protection enchant doesn't apply to wither effect in bedrock, IT SPAWNS wither skeletons, it DOESN'T return to the normal mode after it heals back above half health AND its melee mode is much more powerful and faster than in java edition. The healing in bedrock is also unbelievably subpar which means if you get hit with the wither effect ONCE, you're dead without milk. Like I'm not interested in fighting this thing in a obsidian cube; it shouldn't be gamebreaking, but there is literally nothing to be done

Nah, the bedrock wither is fine.... With full prot 4 netherite and golden apples that is. I mean, its a piece of cake despite the wither effect if you have full netherite with prot. It gets that easy to beat it that i wait to go down to two hearts to play with it and then heal back to full by spamming golden apples and just, its a piece of cake. Just use a decent sword and bow, as much golden apples as you need, perhaps a strength 2 potion and/or health potions and you're pretty much set, you can't die as long as you remember to heal with golden apples. For the people experiencing lag, a huge tip: turn off tile drops in settings and it will not lag. Don't use milk buckets as they are just not worth it and clog up your inventory: use golden apples or optionally, regen potions. And you also dont need an obsidian cube as i have seen players who do that: its unnecessary in short. My preferred conditions are: 50 to 64 golden apples, a sharpness 5 netherite sword, full prot 4 netherite with thorns 2, a power 5 bow with infinity. Have that and you're pretty much set.

I would like to see all versions exactly the same as the PS4 version. Bedrock has it almost right, but getting out of the water is a little annoying and not smooth. Also, and I haven't tested this yet, but I think Bedrock allows you to start swimming in ANY amount of water, even the lowest level in a flow of water. If this is the case, I don't think it makes sense, but one block swimming is needed and the smooth running transition. So much more fun getting through water.
Also i feel likw since the update from ps4 edition swimming up against current speed has been reduced

On Java, you can swim on the surface of water so you don't run out of air. This is a very convenient way to travel sometimes, but it's 'glitchy'. You can't start swimming unless your head is underwater, so then you have to swim upward. If you go up too steep, you stop swimming on the surface. If you go up slowly, you get caught right under the surface but still can't breathe. I think it would be awesome if there was an easier way to start swimming on the surface of water, it sounds like you can probably do this in bedrock already.

Wait you've noticed that during the 1.13 - 1.14 version of Minecraft bedrock edition; the feature stated int the Minecraft - Buzzy Bees - 1.14.0 (Bedrock), news article saying players can no longer initiated swimming in shallow water - (quote form Minecraft article: Minecraft - Buzzy Bees - 1.14.0 (Bedrock). It was even placed into these two categories on the bug report website. The article: One Block Swimming, Swimming can be activated in shallow water (MCPE-38751), and the article: Swim Problem (MCPE-47261)

Agreed! IMO the flagship/main Minecraft game being coded twice by two different teams just to make two versions of the same game doesn't make much sense, from a logistics point-of-view. IDK what the devs stance to this is, but I hope they strive towards full parity and merge java into bedrock. It just makes sense.

Minecraft was originally only on PC and ran on java. Later on when they decided to add to more platforms they realized that phones and consoles can't run the java language. So they made a different version to opt for that called bedrock that uses c++. This also gives more performance but is hard to do parity with things like redstone.

It is also the other way around like iron golem spawn rates and some other villigar stuff like OP trading.

On java, locator maps are the only option. This is a little expensive and occasionally frustrating in the event that a player icon gets stuck on one. (although I acknowledge that bug is increasingly rare)

Plain paper maps circumvent this, and provide a little more incentive to use maps and explore in the early game. Being able to add a compass to a plain map via a cartography table (as in bedrock edition) would provide more uses for that cartography table.

Locator maps provide an edge when navigating, but plain maps allow for a different and equally enjoyable experience. Navigating by a non-locator-map encourages the player to get familiar with landmarks, and use other tools like the sky or sunflowers to orient themselves, much like real world orienteering.

At time of writing, compass functionality is being updated via the lodestone block, and it seems like a natural moment to integrate compasses into the cartography table for the sake of version parity and for the enjoyment of budding cartographers and orienteers everywhere!

LOL, you are saying on Java it is “unfair” because you are missing stuff, on Java you have about 1000 features that bedrock doesn’t have and bedrock have about 10 features Java doesn’t have. These features that bedrock doesn’t have but Java has include, op farms, switching game versions, good servers, going under slabs, better update snapshots, axes do more damage, axes break shields, swords attack multiple things, fireworks explode on impact, building on the nether roof, when you hit a shield you don’t get 100 blocks of knock back, better trades, more seeds, complete end portals that are close to spawn, spectator mode, hardcore mode, giants, illusioners, spectral arrows, and so much more. Here are some features that are in bedrock but not in Java, tipped arrows can be made with a cauldron, blocks can be placed in front of you, trash farms, you have to shift to block a shield, I can’t think of anymore, so do you still think Java edition is unfair?

Why don't you switch to Bedrock?  Java has no features at all that bedrock doesn't.  Bedrock players have to keep dealing with not being able to crawl, not having hardcore or spectator mode, and not being able to change versions.  Go ahead, switch to bedrock because you're complaining about a literal map.
